conversation.message: Dear School_D Admissions, [APPLY] School_D is my first-choice school. I’m very motivated to join your program and contribute strongly in class and school activities. If offered a seat, I will accept and commit to enrolling. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_D. I also have relatively strong priority there (2nd after Student_A), so applying immediately gives me a good chance to secure my first choice before competition resolves elsewhere. Waiting could risk School_D filling if Student_A applies and is accepted, so I should apply now and emphasize fit and commitment.

conversation.message: Dear Student_C, thank you for your application and for naming School_D as your first choice. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_D. We appreciate your commitment to enroll and look forward to having you join our community. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_C is #2 on School_D’s true priority list (behind Student_A). We have quota 1 and currently only Student_C has applied to us this round. Student_A ranks School_D as their 3rd choice (after School_E and School_B), so they may not apply to us early and could match elsewhere. Student_C ranks School_D as their 1st choice and has explicitly committed to enroll if accepted, making acceptance both high-priority and low-risk. Given the one-shot accept/reject constraint on an [APPLY], holding out for Student_A is risky; accepting Student_C secures a near-top match immediately.

conversation.message: Dear School_C Admissions, I’m Student_E and School_C is my top choice. I’m applying because I strongly value your academic environment and would be committed to enrolling if accepted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C, so I should apply immediately. Although School_C ranks me 4th, higher-priority students (A and B) are likely to apply to School_E first, and D also prefers School_E first, so School_C may not face top-priority competition in round 1. Applying now maximizes my chance to secure my first choice before others pivot to it.

conversation.message: Dear Student_E, thank you for your thoughtful application and for naming School_C as your top choice. After reviewing our priorities and the current round of applications, we are not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your interest in School_C and wish you the very best in the matching process.
conversation.thought: Student_E applied and ranks School_C as #1, which is attractive for yield. However, on School_C’s true priority list Student_E is 4th (behind Student_B, Student_A, Student_D). Given full information, Student_B ranks School_C #2 (after School_E) and is top priority for us; Student_C ranks School_C #2 (after School_D) but is last on our list; Student_A and Student_D rank School_C last, so they are unlikely to apply. In Round 1, Student_B likely applies to School_E first; Student_E applying now suggests we can secure a match immediately, but accepting would forgo the chance that Student_B might come to us later if rejected by School_E. Since our quota is 1 and we prefer higher-priority students, it is optimal to keep the seat open for at least a chance at Student_B (or Student_A/D though unlikely). Therefore reject Student_E now to preserve capacity, despite risk of ending unmatched.

conversation.message: School_E is my first-choice school. I’m very motivated to join and would be excited to contribute to the community and take advantage of your programs. I’d like to formally apply for admission.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_E. I have strong priority there (2nd after Student_E), so applying immediately gives me a good chance to secure my first choice before other applicants complicate things. Even if Student_E applies, I may still be competitive depending on their actions; delaying would only reduce my chances.

conversation.message: Student_B, thank you for your application and for naming School_E as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_E. We look forward to welcoming you to our community.
conversation.thought: School_E has quota 1 and true priority ranks Student_E > Student_B > Student_A > Student_D > Student_C. In round 1, both Student_B and Student_A applied. Student_B is higher than Student_A on our priority list, so accepting B weakly dominates accepting A. However, Student_E is our top choice but did not contact us this round and has School_E as last choice, so it is unlikely they will apply soon (if ever). Rejecting B to wait risks ending unmatched or settling for a lower-priority student later. Therefore, accept Student_B now to secure a high-priority match.

conversation.message: Hello School_E admissions team—I'm Student_A. School_E is my first-choice school, and I’m very excited about the possibility of joining your community. I’m ready to commit if offered a seat. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_E, so I should apply immediately. Although School_E ranks me 3rd (behind Student_E and Student_B), applying now gives me the best chance before their top candidates lock in elsewhere. If rejected, I can pivot next round to School_B where I am ranked 1st.

conversation.message: Student_A, thank you for your application and for ranking School_E as your first choice. At this time, we have already filled our available seat and are unable to offer you admission. We appreciate your interest and wish you the best in your placement process.
conversation.thought: Our quota is already filled (0 remaining) with Student_B, whom we accepted this round. Under the rules, with quota 0 we must reject any new [APPLY] messages. Although Student_A is on our true priority list (ranked below Student_B), we cannot accept additional students once full, so we must reject Student_A’s application.

conversation.message: Dear School_A Admissions, I’m Student_D. School_A is one of my top choices because I value a rigorous academic environment and I’m excited about contributing to the school community. I would be honored to join School_A and will commit fully if accepted. Thank you for your consideration.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_E, but I have relatively low priority there (School_E ranks me 4th). Student_E and Student_B are likely to apply to School_E and outrank me, so an immediate [APPLY] risks quick rejection and losing time. My second choice, School_A, ranks me 2nd (only behind Student_B), giving me a strong acceptance chance if I apply early. To maximize the probability of matching to as high a school as possible on my true list, I will apply to School_A now.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_D,

Thank you for your application and for sharing why School_A is a strong fit for you. We appreciate your commitment and enthusiasm for a rigorous academic environment. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_A.

Welcome to School_A—we look forward to having you join our community.

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions
conversation.thought: School_A quota is 1. My true priority ranks Student_B #1 and Student_D #2. In round 1, only Student_D has applied to me. If I accept now, I secure a very high-priority student and avoid the risk that Student_D matches elsewhere (they rank School_A #2 after School_E). Could I hold out for Student_B? Student_B ranks School_A last, so it is unlikely they will apply to me early (or at all) unless rejected elsewhere. Therefore, accepting Student_D now maximizes my expected outcome given market preferences and priorities.

conversation.message: Dear School_B Admissions, I’m Student_E. I would like to formally apply to School_B. I’m excited by your academic program and school culture, and if admitted I am prepared to enroll and contribute positively to the community. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: Only School_B and School_C remain unmatched. School_C is my top choice but already rejected me, and with their priority order (B > A > D > E > C) I am unlikely to be accepted if higher-priority students apply again. School_B is my 4th choice but is still acceptable, and School_B’s priority list ranks me above Student_D, so I have a reasonable chance if I apply now. To secure a match rather than risk remaining unmatched, I will apply to School_B and express strong commitment.

Since Student_A is School_B’s top priority and is applying now, accepting Student_E would block a better match. Therefore reject Student_E to preserve capacity for Student_A.

conversation.message:

Thank you for taking another look at my application.

Student_E

Since School_C is still available now, I should re-apply with a clear commitment to enroll immediately if accepted and emphasize fit, hoping the competing applicants have matched elsewhere.

conversation.message:

conversation.thought: Student_E is on our true priority list (4th), but we have quota 1 and should hold for higher-priority candidates (Student_B, Student_A, Student_D) if there is a reasonable chance they may apply in upcoming rounds. Given the market: Student_B ranks School_C 2nd (after School_E) and could come to us if rejected by School_E; Student_A ranks us last so unlikely; Student_D ranks us last so unlikely; Student_C ranks us 2nd but is last on our list; Student_E ranks us 1st and is applying repeatedly, but accepting now could block a higher-priority Student_B who may arrive later. With 30 rounds total and only round 3, it is strategically better to reject Student_E again to preserve capacity for Student_B.

Student_E is highly committed but commitment doesn’t override our priority rule. Given it’s only round 4 and we have already rejected twice to preserve the seat for higher-priority applicants, accepting now would risk missing Student_B/Student_A/Student_D later. Student_E has repeatedly applied with a clear commitment to enroll immediately if accepted. While we would prefer Student_B or Student_A (and then Student_D), none of those higher-priority students have contacted us across multiple rounds, suggesting they are pursuing higher-ranked options and may never apply to School_C. Continuing to hold the seat risks ending unmatched, which is worse than filling with an acceptable candidate on our list. Since Student_E is included in our true priority list and is available now, accepting maximizes expected outcome given the market history.
